quote: We rolled up the pavement start easy. A one-man break (Rob Smallman) went up the road. Once we turn off the main highway and start the initial climb proper I went to the front and kept a hard tempo.

I took a midseason break/down week the week before Crusher and just mentally unchecked. It was great, and I know it was needed to prioritize the goals I have for the second half of the season. With that, I have been known for my details and preparation leading into an event.

We were caught by the men's pack on the pavement section which is a false flat. As the women's field was swallowed by the men's field, I couldn't see where the women were at. I was frustrated and annoyed.

Halfway up the first climb, I caught up with Sarah Sturm and we stayed together for most of the next 2 hours. We joked about how much more climbing we had left and tried to reassure each other that settling into our own pace was wise...
I just knew that as a rider myself, I was really craving something completely different than the run-of-the-mill events that I'd been participating in for 25+ years.

Gearing was made simple with the mullet set up, I ran a 46t front chain ring and a SRAM Eagle 10-50t rear cassette and felt this was perfect for the steep climbs, but also able to push power on the flat middle section

In terms of gearing, my recommendation for the average rider is something close to a '1 to 1' low-end gear ratio to tackle the climbs. For instance, a 34-tooth front chainring with a 32 tooth cog in the rear.
HED Emporia GC3 pro wheels with WTB Vulpine 40's, running 29psi front and 31psi rear for pressure
For tires, I recommend erring on the side of caution with the variability of conditions you can encounter.
Trek Checkpoint was a dream with the isospeed evening out that washboard descending

ABUS gamechanger 2.0â€¦..yeah you read that right, new model to be available soon which includes more vents. I wouldn't normally opt for an aero helmet on a climbing race, but I wanted to test out the new vents and they were great!
For the first three to four years you were seeing a pretty even distribution of cyclocross and mountain bikes along with quite a few 'Frankenbikes.
As we hit the notorious sandy and hot pit, I opted to up the pace slightly
You know, I think we really have the proverbial 'kitchen sink' when it comes to types of surfaces riders will encounter on the course.
As we hit the notorious sandy and hot pit, I opted to up the pace slightly and try to be at the front of the group we were with since I didn't want to get stuck behind any of the guys.

We rolled with a fairly large group through the pavement flat loop, which I was thankful for given the headwinds. It took some effort to get people to echelon together, but eventually we were rolling.
Last year, I did not carry a pack and stopped to refill 2 bottles in less than 30s on the last climb. I personally just did not want to carry a pack with the extra weight.
Skratch superfuel in the bottles and SIS gels, 110g of carb per hour consumed
I shifted 1,049 times during the 69 mile race

The first couple of years there was a cap imposed on the event by a land agency, but now the cap is self-imposed in the interest of keeping it manageable on my end and also as an attempt to preserve a certain 'vibe' I think we've been able to create.
The 13th annual event, started by Utah legend Burke Swindlehurst and now promoted by Life Time, saw 800 participants from 33 states and 7 countries across the various fields.

We have 600 riders registered this year, which is the same cap we have had in-place now for four years, and though the race technically hasn't 'grown' for a while now, it continues to pick-up speed in terms of how quickly it fills to capacity.
